title: The Lady Tasting Tea: How Statistics Revolutionized Science in the Twentieth Century

This popular history examines the application of statistics and probability to scientific problems in the twentieth century, shaping the story around the lives and accomplishments of pioneers such as Ronald Fisher

note: and math books for science collections (for example, applications of math to other disciplines).
title: Guide to Information Sources in Mathematics and Statistics

This is a guide to sources of information about mathematics and statistics; the target market is librarians, but researchers will also find it useful. Categories include finding tools, journals, reference books, biographical and historical materials

Reliability and Validity Assessment. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage. One of the earliest entries in the Sage “little green books” series, this volume introduces classical methods to evaluate reliability and validity assessment, and gives a brief discussion of factor analytic methods
Surrogate endpoints and FDA’s accelerated approval process

Fleming examines the use of surrogate endpoints in clinical trials intended to provide definitive evidence about the benefits of drugs and other treatments, and describes several situations in which a treatment apparently effective on surrogate endpoints might not be effective with regard to a true clinical endpoint

container-title: In an article based on 104 clinical trials, Michiels and colleagues examine the usefulness of two surrogate endpoints in evaluating the success of treating locally advanced head and neck squamous-cell cancer
note: They conclude that eventfree survival correlates more closely than does locoregional control with overall survival (the true clinical endpoint).
title: Measurement Theory and Practice: The World Through Quantification

Hand provides an excellent discussion of the theory and practice of measurement, including chapters devoted to special problems in the fields of psychology, medicine, the physical sciences, and economics and the social sciences
Surrogate endpoints for overall survival in locally advanced head and neck cancer: Meta-analyses of individual patient data
The earth is round (p < .05
This is a classic article by one of the most vocal critics of the enshrinement of alpha = 0.05 as absolute indicator of the statistical significance or lack thereof
Statistics for Real-Life Sample Surveys: Non-Simple-Random Samples and Weighted Data
This is a well-written guide to sampling and the analysis of survey data when simple random sampling is not possible (which is most of the time

container-title: This classic textbook in inferential statistics includes a chapter on data transformation
title: Data Analysis and Regression: A Second Course in Statistics
• National Institute of Standards and Technology. Engineering Statistics Handbook: Gallery of Distributions
tion3/eda366.htm. This is a nice presentation of 19 common statistical distributions, including ample illustrations, formulas, and common uses for each
Sampling and the census: Improving the decennial count
This clearly written article discusses problems with the data collection efforts of the U.S. census and the controversy over using sampling as part of the process
This Internet site has links to many Java simulations demonstrating statistical concepts, including the central limit theorem, confidence intervals, and data transformations
Visualizing Data

This book discusses effective graphical presentation of data with many examples; it also includes a discussion of the visual and psychological principles that lie behind effective graphical presentation of information

note: This discusses robust statistical methods, including trimmed means, and argues for their wider use.
title: Modern statistical methods: An easy way to maximize the accuracy and power of your research
Creating More Effective Graphs

An easy-to-use guide that shows good and bad examples of graphs presenting the same information, this book always has an eye to using graphical techniques to communicate statistical information more effectively
The Visual Display of Quantitative Information

This book is a landmark that forever changed the way researchers use graphics to display information. Admirers of Tufte’s sometimes contentious approach will want to check out his other works as well, including Beautiful Evidence
Data-based choice of histogram bin width
Not for the faint of heart or the mathematically underprepared, but this book is a thorough technical investigation of various rules for determining the appropriate number of bins for a histogram

note: do we divide by (n − 1) rather than n?
title: Why divide by N-1?
This is a clear and detailed explanation of a question that invariably arises in statistics classes and proves surprisingly difficult to answer: why, when calculating the sample variance
Stature and status: Height, ability, and labor market outcomes
This article discusses the positive relationship between height and income, arguing that this observed relationship is due to the positive relationship between height and cognitive ability

container-title: Journal of the American Statistical Association
title: Statistics and causal inference
This describes the problematic relationship between the need to determine causal inference and the statistical tools available to analyze certain types of data

note: This is perhaps the most influential paper on measures of association in the history of psychology.
title: The proof and measurement of association between two things
Galton, Pearson, and the peas. A brief history of linear regression for statistics instructors
This is a very readable introduction to the development of ideas underlying correlation and regression

note: This is an excellent textbook introduction to simple and multiple regression.
title: Applied Multiple Regression/Correlation Analysis for the Behavioral Sciences
An Introduction to Generalized Linear Models
One of the Sage “little green books,” this slim (72 pages) volume provides an excellent overview of the general linear model for those who are comfortable with reading mathematical equations

note: This is the original paper on regression to the mean.
title: Regression towards mediocrity in hereditary stature
Consequences of failure to meet assumptions underlying the analysis of variance and covariance
This is a technical paper on the assumptions underlying ANOVA and ANCOVA and the consequences for the analysis when they are not met

Interpreting and Using Regression. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications. A Sage “little green book,” this offers an excellent introduction to the correct (and cautious) interpretation of multiple linear regression models
Interaction Effects in Multiple Regression
little green book,” this one offers a straightforward synthesis of theory and practice regarding interaction effects in regression models
A caution regarding rules of thumb for variance inflation factors

O’Brien argues that applying conventional rules of thumb exaggerates the problems caused by multicollinearity and that typical solutions to perceived multicollinearity can cause more problems than they solve
Nonlinear Regression Analysis and Its Applications
This is a very practical textbook introduction to curve fitting and nonlinear modeling

container-title: Philadephia: Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics. This is a classic textbook on resampling methods
title: The Jackknife, the Bootstrap, and Other Resampling References Plans
Applied Logistic Regression
This is a practical presentation of logistic regression and its applications for advanced students and specialists

note: This paper extends the Wilcoxon Mann Whitney-U test to unequal sample sizes.
title: On a test of whether one of two random variables is stochastically larger than the other
Individual comparisons by ranking methods
This is the original paper describing the Wilcoxon Mann Whitney-U test for equal sample sizes

publisher: American Cyanamid. Revised with R.A. Wilcox
title: Some Rapid Approximate Statistical Procedures
These are the original and revised papers that describe Wilcoxon’s Signed Rank Test, including a table of critical values
Making Hard Decisions: An Introduction to Decision Analysis
This textbook emphasizes the logical and philosophical problems behind decision making while discussing different approaches to decision analysis

note: forecasting, hypothesis testing, decision theory, and linear programming.
title: Numbers Guide: The Essentials of Business Numeracy
This handy pocket guide describes numerical operations useful in business, including index numbers, interest and mortgage problems

container-title: Conference on the Measurement of Inflation
title: The Boskin Commission Report and its aftermath

note: which suggested that the CPI overstated inflation.
title: This summarizes criticisms regarding the U.S. Consumer Price Index, including those identified by the 1995 Boskin Commission report

collection-title: This popular time series textbook includes code in R (a free computer language) to execute time series analyses
title: Time Series Analysis and Its Applications: With R Examples
The Quality Toolbox

This reference book provides an overview and brief history of Quality Improvement (QI), followed by an alphabetical guide to QI tools, including standard statistical and graphical procedures such as the box plot and hypothesis testing, and more specialized tools such as control charts and fishbone diagrams
References analysis includes formulas and examples for the most common study designs used in medicine and epidemiology
Epidemiology in Medicine
This is an easy-to-read introduction to epidemiology, from basic concepts through study design and types of analysis
Principles of Biostatistics
This introduction to biostatistics is suitable for an undergraduate course; it’s less detailed and easier to use than Rosner’s text
Fundamentals of Biostatistics
An excellent introduction to biostatics for graduate students or those who are willing to grapple with more theoretical details than are provided in Pagano and Gauvreau’s text
Modern Epidemiology
This is a very thorough discussion of epidemiology, including several chapters written by guest authors, for students willing and able to grapple with the subject

author.literal: • Levesque, Raynald. Raynald’s SPSS Pages. http://www.spsstools.net/.

note: Little and Rubin wrote the book on missing data, and this is the standard reference on the subject. However, it’s not for the faint of heart and assumes considerable mathematical sophistication on the part of the reader.
title: Two websites run by the experienced SPSS programmer Raynald Levesque; both are loaded with tips, tricks, and sample code
Statistical Analysis with Missing Data
Experimental Methodology
This is a very readable and comprehensive introduction to research and experimental design with a focus on educational and psychological topics
Statistical Methods, Experimental Design, and Scientific Inference: A Re-issue of Statistical Methods for Research Workers, the Design of Experiments, and Statistical Methods and Scientific Inference
If you want to read the original rationale for many of the designs and issues described in this chapter, there is no better place than the original source. • The Framingham Heart Study
This is the official website of one of the largest, longest, and most famous References prospective cohort studies in the history of medicine

note: This is the article used as an example of research design in Chapter 18.
title: The interactive effects of alcohol and Temazepam of P300 and reaction time

note: Reprinted in the International Journal of Epidemiology (2009).
title: Ecological correlations and the behavior of individuals
This is a classic paper on the ecological fallacy, demonstrated with data correlating literacy with race and national origin
The central role of the propensity score in observational studies for causal effects
This is the article in which Rosenbaum and Rubin introduced the concept of the propensity score, which is now commonly used in case control studies in medical research
Experimental and Quasi-Experimental Designs for Generalized Causal Inference
This is an updated version of the classic text on research design; not the best book for beginners but essential for anyone who really wants to understand the issues
That Old Black Magic
This article examines the validity for claims of the “Sports Illustrated jinx,” a phenomenon often cited as a classic case of regression to the mean

title: interpretation of descriptive test-retest reliability (multiple-occasions statistics, 466–470 reliability), 11 issues in research design, 463–465 tetrachoric correlation coefficient, 403 misusing statistics, 458–459 theoretical probability distributions in Age of Information, xiii about, 46 stem-and-leaf plot, 105 continuous distribution, 46, 47–50 stepwise methods for building regression three-way ANOVA, 229–232 models Thurstone, Louis Leon

container-title: She has published two previous books: An Intermediate Guide to SPSS Programming: Using Syntax for Data Management
note: SAGE Publications, 2004) and Secondary Data Sources for Public Health (Cambridge University Press, 2007) and edited the Encyclopedia of Epidemiology for SAGE Publications (2007). Her latest book, Healthcare Systems Around the World: A Comparative Guide will be published by SAGE in 2013.
title: Sarah Boslaugh holds a PhD in Research and Evaluation from the City University of New York and has been working as a statistical analyst for 20 years in a variety of professional settings, including the New York City Board of Education, the Institutional Research Office of the City University of New York, Montefiore Medical Center, the Virginia Department of Social Services, Magellan Health Services, Washington University School of Medicine, and BJC HealthCare. She has taught statistics in several different contexts and is currently a grant and proposal writer at Kennesaw State University
